info: Revenue reported at approximately $141.9 million and $145.2 million for recent fiscal periods.

Charter Communications reports an aggregate market value of approximately $28.3 billion for its non‑affiliate Class A common stock and 141,946,426 Class A shares outstanding (plus 1 Class B share) as of December 31, 2024, confirming its status as a large accelerated filer.

Charter serves ~57 million homes and businesses across 41 states. In 2024 it rolled out symmetric Internet in eight markets and 2 × 1 Gbps service in two markets, launched Wi‑Fi 7 routers (>10 Gbps), and introduced the Life Unlimited brand with simplified pricing. Rural construction spending reached $5.5 bn, activating 813 k passings. Total customer relationships fell modestly to 31.5 million from 32.1 million, with residential accounts at 29.3 million. Monthly revenue per residential customer rose to $121.04 (up from $119.89) and per SMB to $164.08. Internet, video, mobile and voice subscriber counts showed slight declines year‑over‑year. The network evolution plan targeting multi‑gigabit speeds via DOCSIS 4.0 and high‑split spectrum (1.8 GHz) is slated for completion by 2027, and accounts past‑due metrics improved markedly.

The company highlighted continued expansion of its VoIP, video and broadband services, adding seamless entertainment apps and a 100,000‑title VOD library, while advancing network capacity with DOCSIS 3.1, planned DOCSIS 4.0 and spectrum upgrades to 1.8 GHz. It reported ownership of 26.8% of a regional sports network, 210 CBRS licenses for a future 5G data‑only network, and a push into rural broadband serving 1.7 million unserved passings; $5.5 billion has been spent to activate 813,000 passings with total planned investment over $8 billion, including $2 billion of government support. Advertising reach spans up to 100 channels in more than 90 markets, and in‑house field teams performed about 85% of service transactions. Approximately 500 million devices are connected to its Wi‑Fi network.

The company emphasizes self‑service channels and a bundled marketing approach, recently launching the Life Unlimited brand in September 2024. It faces intense competition across residential and business Internet, video, mobile, voice and advertising segments, including FTTH rivals offering up to 1 Gbps+ and multiple virtual MVPDs. Regulatory risks are highlighted, notably FCC pole‑attachment rules, must‑carry/retransmission consent costs, and evolving net‑neutrality classifications. The pending Liberty Broadband combination, announced November 12 2024, will convert Liberty shares into Charter Class A stock at a 0.236 ratio, involve a $2.6 billion debt repayment, a $180 million liquidation preference conversion, and a potential $420 million corporate‑level tax liability, with closing targeted for June 30 2027.

Regulatory uncertainty surrounds franchise renewals, FCC reclassifications of Internet services, state net‑neutrality and digital‑discrimination rules, and FTC termination rules, all of which could materially affect the business; the company faces ongoing legal challenges that may alter service obligations. It has been awarded over $2 billion in federal and state subsidies to fund broadband construction for roughly 1.7 million passings, with penalties possible for non‑compliance. Competitive pressures across Internet, mobile, voice and video services and heightened cybersecurity and network‑disruption risks are also highlighted. The firm employed about 94,500 full‑time equivalents as of year‑end 2024.

The filing highlights extensive operational and external risks, including vulnerability to power outages, natural disasters, cyber‑security breaches, and reliance on a limited set of third‑party vendors whose failure could disrupt service and increase costs. Competitive pressures, rapid technology changes, AI‑related liabilities, and escalating programming expenses may erode margins and customer retention. Significant debt levels and covenant restrictions limit financial flexibility, while ownership stakes by Liberty Broadband and Advance/Newhouse confer substantial governance influence over Charter.

The charter board is fixed at 13 directors, with Liberty Broadband and A/N wielding significant voting power and pre‑emptive rights that can dilute other Class A shareholders. The company faces extensive regulatory and legislative risks across broadband, voice, cable and cybersecurity, including potential new rules, subsidies, and compliance penalties. Ongoing franchise renewals and competition pose additional operational uncertainties. The pending Liberty Broadband merger is subject to numerous closing conditions and a deadline of August 31, 2027; failure could trigger termination fees, market price impacts, and diverted management focus, while incurring substantial transaction costs. Tax exposure may rise as provisions of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act expire at the end of 2025. A 2024 appellate decision and a pending Supreme Court appeal introduce uncertainty around universal service funding.

The filing highlights additional risks from the pending combination with Liberty Broadband and emphasizes a Tier 1 cybersecurity risk classification, though no material cyber incidents have occurred. Governance includes Board audit committee oversight and a dedicated security executive steering committee. Equity repurchases were active in Q4 2024, with ~384 k shares bought for $109 M and additional authority to spend $961 M. The company lost 508 k Internet customers but added 2.12 M mobile lines, spent $2.2 B on subsidized rural construction (activating 393 k passings), and operates in an estimated 57 M homes/businesses across 41 states. Financially, revenue grew 0.9% to $55.1 B, Adjusted EBITDA rose 3.1% to $22.6 B, and income from operations increased 4.5% to $13.1 B.

Revenue grew modestly 0.9% to $55.1B driven by strong mobile line additions, modest internet rate‑mix gains and a 14.8% jump in advertising sales, while video revenues fell 7.5% and voice declined. Capitalized labor and overhead remained high at $2.4B (2024) versus $2.3B (2023). Pension obligations are around $2.2‑$2.4B with net funded assets of $125‑$149M and pension cost fell to $23M in 2024. Operating costs were stable, interest expense ~ $5.2B, and net income rose to $5.85B. Management noted risks from customer churn in internet and video segments.

Residential mobile lines rose 2.05 million, while residential voice customers declined, leading to a $219 million drop in voice revenue partially offset by $146 million rate adjustments. SMB revenue grew $18 million despite a 7,000 customer decline. Enterprise revenue up $113 million and advertising sales up $229 million. Programming costs fell $985 million to $9.7 billion. Other costs of revenue rose $764 million. Net income rose to $5.1 billion and Adjusted EBITDA to $22.6 billion, with free cash flow increasing to $4.3 billion. Total debt stands at $93.8 billion with leverage at 4.13× EBITDA. Share repurchases continued, totaling 2.7 million shares for $822 million in 2024.

Charter continued its share repurchase program, purchasing 0.6 million units for $189 million in 2024 versus 1.1 million units for $427 million in 2023, and retains board authority for up to $961 million of additional purchases. Free cash flow rose by $767 million driven by higher working‑capital releases and EBITDA, while cash balances fell to $459 million. Net operating cash was flat, investing outflows fell to $10.7 billion and financing outflows rose $737 million. Capital expenditures increased to $11.3 billion, with line‑extension spending up to $4.2 billion and total 2025 capex projected around $12 billion. Total debt accreted value stands at $93.9 billion, comprised of senior notes maturing 2026‑2029.

Charter disclosed a extensive debt portfolio with $93.8 bn of principal and $93.9 bn accreted values as of 12/31/2024, $6.3 bn of credit‑facility availability, and $504 m of cross‑currency derivative fair value. In May 2024 it issued $1.5 bn each of 6.100% notes (99.944% price) and 6.550% notes (99.755% price) and used proceeds to repurchase $2.7 bn of existing 4.908% notes and prepay term loans. A December 2024 credit‑agreement amendment created a $5.5 bn Revolving Loan C, retained $960 m Revolving Loan B, and converted loans into $4.5 bn Term A‑7 and $2.5 bn Term B‑5 facilities. Weighted average interest rates were 6.3% on credit‑facility debt, 5.0% on senior notes, yielding a 5.2% blended rate, with 89% of debt fixed‑rate. Sterling‑denominated debt of £625 m ($782 m) and £650 m ($813 m) is hedged via cross‑currency derivatives.

The company uses cross‑currency derivatives to hedge £1.275 billion of sterling debt, with fair value rising to $504 million in 2024 from $440 million in 2023. Weighted average interest rates on credit facilities fell to 6.3% (down from 7.0%) while senior note rates remained at 5.0%, giving a blended rate of 5.2% in 2024. About 89% of total debt was fixed‑rate at year‑end 2024. Management highlighted effective internal controls, completion of a Human Capital Management platform in October 2024, and disclosed executive compensation – the CFO’s base salary of $925,000 with a 175% bonus target and severance provisions – as well as a 57,531‑share insider trading plan. Fixed‑ and variable‑rate debt fair values and average rates for 2025‑2029 and thereafter are detailed in the disclosed tables.

The filing lists signatures of the CEO, CFO and other officers dated January 31 2025, includes 12 directors, and provides an exhibit index of 16 documents covering merger agreements, charter amendments and senior secured notes dated between 2014 and 2024.
The filing lists a series of supplemental indentures and senior note issuances with various interest rates and maturities, reflecting the company’s ongoing debt financing activities across 2016‑2017.

Charter Communications executed multiple supplemental indentures and issued senior secured notes with interest rates ranging from 4.5% to 5.75% and maturities spanning 2029 to 2050, reflecting continued debt financing activity.

Multiple supplemental indentures were filed between 2020 and 2021, introducing various senior and senior secured notes with interest rates ranging from 2.3% to 4.5% and maturities through 2061, indicating ongoing debt financing activity.
Charter issued multiple supplemental indentures between 2021 and 2023, introducing senior notes with interest rates ranging from 2.250% to 7.375% and maturities spanning 2026 to 2063.

The filing references multiple supplemental indentures, including Charter Communications' 6.100% senior notes due 2029 and 6.550% senior notes due 2034, alongside historic Time Warner indentures dating back to the early 1990s.

The excerpt enumerates numerous supplemental indentures, exchange and registration rights agreements, and debt issuances for Charter Communications, highlighting a series of debentures and senior notes with varied interest rates and maturities, indicating ongoing debt financing activities.

The company executed multiple exchange and registration rights agreements between 2017 and 2022, issuing senior notes with interest rates from 3.75% to 6.375% and maturities spanning 2027 to 2047, reflecting ongoing debt financing activity.
Multiple amendments and restatements to the company's credit and guarantee agreements were filed between 2016 and 2023, reflecting ongoing financing arrangements.

Multiple amendments to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (Amendments No. 4‑6 dated 2023‑2024) and various ancillary agreements (registration rights, escrow, collateral, intercreditor, LLC and exchange agreements) filed between 2016 and 2024 are referenced, reflecting continued financing and structural arrangements.

The excerpt lists numerous exhibit references to Charter Communications’ executive compensation agreements, stock incentive plans, and related filings, but provides no material operational or financial details.

The filing lists numerous amendments and new agreements related to Charter Communications' stock incentive plans, employment contracts, letter and voting agreements, and compensation policies, including updates to the 2019 Stock Incentive Plan, performance‑vesting options, and agreements with Liberty Broadband, Advance/Newhouse Partnership, and related parties, as well as the adoption of a compensation recovery policy (effective Oct 1 2023) and securities trading policy (effective Oct 2024).

KPMG issued an unqualified audit opinion and affirmed effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024. A critical audit matter emphasized the $47.4 billion residential and SMB revenue, highlighting the complexity of IT systems and data volume. 2024 financial results showed revenue of $55,085 million, operating income of $13,118 million, net income attributable to Charter shareholders of $5,083 million and basic EPS of $35.53.

Charter posted stable consolidated net income around $5.8 billion from 2022‑2024, with operating cash flow of roughly $14.4 billion each year. The company continued to borrow net long‑term debt while repaying a larger amount, resulting in a net cash outflow from financing activities. Treasury stock purchases were reduced in 2024. RDOF government subsidies contributed roughly $108‑$116 million annually, and no impairments of long‑lived assets were recorded. Cash balances fell to $506 million at year‑end 2024.

The company relies on Level 1‑3 fair‑value hierarchies and significant judgment for valuation. It received approximately $1.1 billion in federal RDOF subsidies and $1.3 billion in state broadband grants (about $1.1 billion formalized). RDOF subsidy revenue was $108 million in 2024, $116 million in 2023 and $107 million in 2022. Depreciation expense rose to $7.8 billion in 2024. Property, plant and equipment netted $42.9 billion in 2024. Indefinite‑life intangible assets include $67.5 billion of franchises and $29.7 billion of goodwill. Finite‑life intangibles generated $838 million of amortization in 2024, with future amortization projected at $1.108 billion through 2029.

Company recorded a $331 million net loss on investments in 2024 and continues to estimate amortization expense of $592 million for 2025, decreasing in subsequent years. It expanded its supply chain finance program, confirming $1.45 billion of vendor obligations and ending the year with $576 million outstanding, while a deferred payment program left $758 million in short‑term borrowings. Operating lease expense rose to $516 million in 2024, with total lease liabilities of $1.413 billion. Total debt reached $93.779 billion, comprised of senior unsecured notes, senior secured notes and credit facilities, and the company issued $3 billion of new senior secured notes at roughly 99.9% of face value, using proceeds for a $2.7 billion tender repurchase that generated a $9 million gain on extinguishment of debt.

The company recorded an $8 million loss on extinguishment of debt in 2024 and $3 million losses in each of 2023 and 2022 tied to senior note repurchases of $1.5 billion and $3.0 billion respectively. A December 2024 amendment reshaped its credit facilities, creating a new Revolving Loan C and converting portions of term loans. Total credit facility commitments now stand at $10.3 billion, with a consolidated leverage ratio of 2.7, comfortably below covenant limits. Outstanding balances include Term A‑6 ($437 m), Term A‑7 ($4.5 b), Term B‑3 ($737 m), Term B‑4 ($2.0 b), Term B‑5 ($2.5 b), Revolving Loan B capacity $960 m and Revolving Loan C balance $140 m with $5.5 b capacity. Utilized revolving capacity is $35 m against $425 m of letters of credit. SOFR rates were 4.3% in 2024 and 5.4% in 2023. Future principal and interest payments through 2029 total $93.8 b and $60.9 b respectively. The EIP Financing Facility carries a 5.78% rate, permits borrowing up to $1.25 b, holds $1.1 b of assets, $1.6 b of pledged receivables and $47 m of restricted cash.

The company disclosed a $1.6 billion EIP receivable financing facility with $47 million restricted cash, completed share buybacks of 3.71 million shares in 2024 and retained $961 million board authority for further repurchases, and reported noncontrolling interest holdings of 16.5 million units with net income allocations of $767 million in 2024. Revenue grew modestly to $55.085 billion in 2024, driven by Internet and video services, while cross‑currency derivative fair value stood at $504 million.

Revenue includes significant government fee pass‑throughs of $941 m, $993 m and $1.1 bn in 2024‑2022, while equipment installment receivables total $967 m (current) and $980 m (non‑current) in 2024. Allowance for doubtful accounts showed a $762 m charge in 2024 and an ending balance of $204 m. Operating expenses were $33.2 bn in 2024, with programming costs at $9.7 bn and stock compensation expense $651 m. Special charges of $139 m and a $12 m disposal loss were recorded in 2024. Other income net was a $387 m loss. The stock incentive plan authorizes up to 23 m shares, with $276 m unrecognized compensation for stock options remaining as of year‑end.

The company measures equity awards at grant‑date fair value using Black‑Scholes and Monte Carlo models, with 2024 assumptions of a 3.9% risk‑free rate, 5.0‑year expected life and 33% volatility. Unrecognized compensation as of 12/31/24 totals $276 M for stock options, $1 M for restricted stock and $396 M for RSUs, to be recognized over 2 years (options/RSUs) and 4 months (restricted stock). Income tax expense for 2024 was $1.65 B, comprising $1.38 B federal and $357 M state current taxes, offset by a $87 M deferred tax benefit.

Tax provision shows sizable effective‑tax adjustments with statutory federal and state taxes of roughly $1.5‑1.6 billion each year, plus uncertain tax positions of $604 million and a $604 million unrecognized tax benefit balance rising to $743 million in 2024. Deferred tax liabilities are dominated by a $20 billion partnership investment, netting $18.8 billion after allowances, and include $88 million (2024) and $55 million (2023) related to indirect subsidiaries. A Tax Receivable Agreement could obligate up to $3.5 billion if future exchanges occur. Net income remained around $5 billion with basic EPS of $35.53 in 2024, and diluted EPS of $34.97. Revenue from HSN/QVC channels modestly grew to $48 million. Ongoing IRS examinations are not expected to be material.

The filing discloses that Gregory Maffei holds about 18.5% of Qurate and 3.7% of Liberty Broadband, while Dr. John Malone holds about 6.5% of Qurate and 48.5% of Liberty Broadband. Qurate generated roughly $48M, $47M and $43M from HSN/QVC in 2024‑2022. Liberty Broadband is slated to merge into Charter, with the transaction expected to close by June 30, 2027 after a spin‑off of GCI; a tax liability over $420M could trigger Charter tax benefits. Charter will repurchase up to $100M of its Class A shares from Liberty Broadband each month. The company recorded equity‑investee payments of $189M, $180M and $213M for 2024‑2022, contractual commitments totaling $10.788B through 2029, pole‑rental costs of $243M‑$207M, franchise fees of $604M‑$730M, and maintains $425M in letters of credit. Ongoing investigations into waste‑disposal practices and various IP lawsuits are noted but not expected to be material. Pension plan data show a projected benefit obligation of $2.426B in 2024 declining to $2.206B year‑end, with related asset and liability movements.

The company terminated its qualified pension plan, recording a $101 million unrealized loss and a $28 million remeasurement loss in 2024, while net periodic pension cost was a $23 million expense versus a $216 million expense in 2023. Plan assets declined to $2.31 billion from $2.55 billion, with the group annuity contract and collective trust funds comprising most of the assets. No cash contributions were made to the qualified plan, and future benefit payments are projected at $209 million in 2025 decreasing to $163 million by 2029, then $741 million over 2030‑34. 401(k) and RAP contributions increased to $574 million in 2024. The parent‑only balance sheet showed growth in assets to $35.5 billion and equity to $15.6 billion, with current liabilities rising to $397 million. The company adopted ASU 2023‑07 for segment disclosures in 2024 and plans early adoption of ASU 2023‑09 and ASU 2024‑03.

Charter's 2024 revenue was $3 million, down from $1 million in 2023 and $4 million in 2022; net income remained around $5 billion each year (2024: $5,083 million, 2023: $4,557 million, 2022: $5,055 million). Operating cash flow was negative (~$1,389 million) while investing activities produced positive cash flow ($2,535 million) and financing activities used cash ($1,146 million), including a $1,213 million treasury‑stock repurchase. Subsidiary cash contributions were negative and distributions were sizable.
